awd_titl_txt: Traveling Wave Approaches for Improved Sensitivity and Spatial Coverage in Continuous-Wave (CW) Electron Paramagnetic Resonance Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
Electron paramagnetic resonance imaging (EPRI) is a low-cost and highly specific imaging technique with significant applications. In medical imaging, EPRI can be used to obtain tissue oxygenation images to identify oxygen-starved areas of tissue. Oxygen-starved areas of cancer are usually more aggressive and harder to treat, so a medical imaging tool to identify hypoxia would be highly useful. A primary advantage of EPRI relative to other medical imaging techniques is the significantly lower cost of its instrumentation. For example, in comparison to magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), EPRI can be performed without using a superconducting magnet. This drastically reduces the cost of constructing, siting, and operating EPRI systems compared to MRI systems. Unlike MRI, however, the technology for using EPRI to perform whole-body human imaging has not yet been developed. One of the primary challenges in further development of EPRI is the difficulty in performing signal excitation at the frequency ranges that are desirable for high-sensitivity imaging. This project addresses this shortcoming by developing novel instrumentations that will ultimately enable EPRI systems to be used for whole-body human imaging. The successful completion of this project has the potential for the development of a low-cost, human imaging technology. Since this technology offers imaging capabilities similar to MRI but at a small fraction of its cost it is expected to   significantly reduce the cost of medical diagnostic techniques based on imaging technologies.  This will likely contribute towards reducing the cost of overall healthcare services provided to the public in the U.S. and around the world. Additionally, this project has important educational impacts, which include increased participation of under-represented students in research and graduate engineering education, active involvement of undergraduate students in research, mentoring K-12 science teachers and curriculum development, and broad dissemination of research results to the public.

The overall objective of this project is to develop new techniques for continuous-wave (CW) electron paramagnetic resonance imaging (EPRI) that enhance its sensitivity and move towards the development of instrumentation capable of whole-body human imaging. Specifically, we propose to develop a traveling-wave (TW) approach for continuous-wave electron-paramagnetic resonance imaging. In the TW approach, RF signal excitation is performed using traveling waves that propagate from a remote antenna or probe inside a waveguide through tissue. In comparison to the conventional reactive near field approach, uniform magnetic fields across a much larger volume can be realized using the TW approach. Therefore, the development of the continuous-wave, TW-EPRI is expected to enable both the necessary volumetric coverage and sufficiently high magnetic field strength needed to perform whole-body human imaging. To accomplish this, we will pursue four aims to develop and study novel, low-cost CW, TW-EPRI instrumentation. These include: 1) develop a CW, traveling-wave EPRI system in a parallel plate waveguide environment to demonstrate feasibility for a traveling wave EPRI system; 2) Develop phased-array transmit techniques for improved magnetic field uniformity in high-frequency (>300 MHz) continuous-wave, TW-EPRI systems; 3) Integrate the imaging system and develop improved reconstruction algorithms; and 4) Develop techniques for accelerating image acquisition speed and improving the sensitivity of CW, TW-EPRI systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The traveling-wave electron paramagnetic resonance imaging (TW-EPRI) is a technology that offers imaging capabilities similar to MRI but at a small fraction of its cost. This can potentially reduce the cost of medical diagnostic techniques of novel imaging technologies and contribute towards reducing the cost of the healthcare services provided to the public in the U.S. and around the world. The TW-EPRI technology offers the ability to non-invasively obtain in vivo tissue measurements such as oxygenation, pH, redox status, and exposure to ionizing radiation. This has significant applications toward human health in a wide range of diseases such as cancer, heart disease, stroke, and ischemic limb disease. The key outcomes of this project are listed below:

 

1)      Development of a continuous-wave, traveling-wave electron paramagnetic resonance imaging in a cylindrical waveguide environment at 1 GHz. We developed a new architecture for a TW-EPRI system consisting of a circular waveguide fed with one or more monopole antennas used to generate a uniform magnetic field distribution in its interior region at a frequency of nearly 1 GHz. The system uses one or more receiver coils to perform electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) imaging in a transmission mode in which the high-frequency magnetic field component of the traveling wave electromagnetic wave generated by the waveguide is received and sensed by the receiver coils. The entire system is placed in a larger water-cooled electromagnet whose intensity can be changed to create the appropriate EPR resonance conditions within the object to be measured. A pair of Helmholtz coils are used to modulate the intensity of this dc magnetic field in the vicinity of the object to be imaged to simplify the task of isolating the desired signal from system noise using a lock-in amplifier. We also developed the complete RF transceiver chain used for transmitting the signal and receiving the modulated EPR signal of the sample and demonstrated that this system can successfully perform electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy in the traveling wave mode at a frequency of 1 GHz. 

 

2)      Integration of the TW-EPR imaging system with gradient coils for three-dimensional imaging. We converted the traveling-wave EPR spectroscopy system described above to a three-dimensional EPR imaging system by integrating the system with a set of gradient coils that allow us to sweep the intensity of the magnetic field in three dimensions and thus localize the region from which the EPR signal is being measured. This enables the system to acquire two-dimensional images of a three-dimensional object in different cut planes that can be controlled at will. Fig. 1 shows a photograph of the main components of this system including the circular waveguide and the gradient coils. Fig. 2 shows a few sample two-dimensional images obtained from this system in different cut planes. In this imaging experiment, the imaging object or phantom consisted of two vials with a diameter of 3 mm containing a powder with sufficient free radicals to have a measurable electron paramagnetic resonance signal.

 

Broader impacts:

The broader impacts of the educational activities conducted in this project include the research-based training and education of graduate and undergraduate students. This work supported the education of two graduate students one of whom completed his M.S. degree in April 2023 and is currently working towards his Ph.D. degree on the same topic. The other graduate student is expected to receive an M.S. degree in Fall of 2024 while continuing to work towards a Ph.D. degree. Both of these Ph.D. students are making excellent progress towards receiving their Ph.D. degrees. Using an REU supplement received for this project, the project also supported the undergraduate research-based educational activities of four undergraduate students. Of these students, two of them continued to pursue advanced graduate level studies after graduating with their B.S. degrees. The findings of this project were also broadly disseminated through the publication of conference papers.
